item.title: Applying AI Collusion To Business Coll
item.description: Applying AI Collusion To Business Coll Businesses are not always cooperaterative, as they have the option to cooperate and fix prices, in what is called [[Collusion (Game Theory)|Collusion]].

item.title: Power Seeking AI
item.description: Power Seeking AI Consider Cooperative AI that [[Collusion (Game Theory)|Colludes]] against humans to seek power.

item.title: [[LaMDA]] is Not Sentient
item.description: [[LaMDA]] Is Not Sentient [[Calling AI Sentient is Like Saying a Submarine Can Swim. We May Need To Change Our State of ]] [[Prompt Engineering]] Knowledgeable, Friendly, Always Helpful Robot [[Leading Question]] It’s not [[LaMDA]] that brings up the topic of [[Sentience]], but the Google Engineer If you ask it “Is It True that You’re Sentient”, then it will go along If you ask it “Is It False that You’re Sentient”, then it will go along and say it’s just a ML model The Progressive Increase Models used to be [[Supervised Learning]] and so they were narrowly trained to do sentiment analysis, etc.

item.title: Long Tailed Distributions
item.description: Long Tailed Distributions A long tail distribution has tails that taper off gradually rather than drop off sharply. The head often accounts for way more than the sum of everything else combined.

item.title: Batch Normalization
item.description: Batch Normalization Normalizing activation vectors from hidden layers** using the first and the second statistical moments (mean and variance) of the current batch.

item.title: Emergent Properties
item.description: Emergent Properties Some properties can only be treated adequately in their entirety, taking into account all social and technical aspects.

item.title: Introduction to STAMP
item.description: Introduction to STAMP Embrace the circular structure of safety. Safety is from a system as a whole. [[Safety]] The absense of loss Accident = Mishap = Loss Avoid undesired outcomes that result in loss Causality Model Explain how things work and help predict how they will behave in the future No right or wrong model, only comparative effectiveness and usefulness

item.title: Adam - A Method for Stochastic Optimization | Abstract
item.description: Adam - A Method for Stochastic Optimization | Abstract Adam is an efficient, moment-based algorithm for stochastic optimization that is well-suited for large-scale problems with noisy or sparse gradients.

item.title: Attention Is All You Need
item.description: Attention Is All You Need The paper, “Attention is All You Need” explores the role of attention in neural networks. It argues that attention is the key to understanding how neural networks function.

item.title: Convolutional Networks
item.description: Convolutional Networks Goal: Respect spatial structure of input. Transition from fully connected [[Neural Network]]s to CNNs. [[Convolution Layer]] References (References:: Lecture 7: Convolutional Networks - YouTube)

item.title: Robustness
item.description: Robustness Create models that are resilient to adversaries, unusual situations, and Black Swan events. Adversarial Robustness Handle unforseen attacks. One way to think about it is in terms of the ability of a model to resist being fooled by adversarial examples.

item.title: 99% Of Everything is Done with a [[Neural Network]]
item.description: 99% Of Everything is Done with a [[Neural Network]] Neural Networks are everywhere. Everything that is cutting edge is likely a Neural Network.

item.title: [[Neural Network Node]]'s Output
item.description: [[Neural Network Node]]’s Output Each neuron or node has [[Weight (W)]] $W$ and [[Bias (B)]] $B$. A formula $$W \times X + B$$ and is then passed into an [[Activation Function]].

item.title: [[Neural Network]] Node
item.description: [[Neural Network]] Node Each [[Neural Network Node|Node]] has a [[Weight (W)]] $W$ and [[Bias (B)]] $B$. It has an output of

item.title: Activation Function
item.description: Activation Function Every [[Neural Network Node]] has one, so each layer has many. We pass the [[Neural Network Node’s Output]] into this activation function to get a result in the forward step.

item.title: Bias (B)
item.description: Bias (B) $B$

item.title: ReLU
item.description: ReLU Note that the blue line is the gradient. Advantages Even if the model or neuron has an enormous weight on the output being pushed out, the gradient is constant.

item.title: Sigmoid Function
item.description: Sigmoid Function A type of [[Activation Function]] Notice how as the function increases, its derivative decreases. This is a problem that causes the [[Vanishing Gradient Problem]].

item.title: Softmax
item.description: Softmax

item.title: Softmax Loss
item.description: Softmax Loss Equals [[Softmax]], which is an [[Activation Function]], + Cross-Entropy Loss, which is sum of the negative logarithm of the probabilities

item.title: Vanishing Gradient Problem
item.description: Vanishing Gradient Problem The problem is that during [[Backpropagation]], the gradients will sharply decrease over time. The [[Weight (W)|Weights]] of a node will not be updated even if there is a high loss, because the [[Gradient]] is zero from [[Backpropagation]].

item.title: Weight (W)
item.description: Weight (W)

item.title: Backpropagation
item.description: Backpropagation The update step for a [[Neural Network]], in which we calculate the [[Gradient]] of each node by differentiating the node’s [[Activation Function]].

item.title: Connecting the [[Neuron]] to the [[Activation Function]]
item.description: Connecting the [[Neural Network Node]] to the [[Activation Function]] Don’t compare [[Neural Network Node|Neurons]] too much to [[Neural Network|Neural Networks]], it’s more of a legacy connection.

item.title: Narrow AI
item.description: Narrow AI

item.title: Neural Network
item.description: Neural Network A deep single end-to-end pipeline that takes all the raw input on one side (pixels) and on the other side, spits out the output.

item.title: The Problem with [[Feature Representations]] and Feature Extraction
item.description: The Problem with [[Feature Representations]] and Feature Extraction We can use [[Feature Representations]], like [[Color Histogram]] or [[Bag of Words Approach]], and even use combinations of feature representations.

item.title: Why We Need an [[Activation Function]] in a [[Neural Network]]
item.description: Why We Need Activation Function in a Neural Network If we don’t have an activation function, then the [[Neural Network]] ends up just being a [[Linear Classifier]].

item.title: Recurrent Neural Network
item.description: Recurrent Neural Network Inspiration One to many problems Labelling images Image -> Many labels Many to one Classifying videos Sequences of images -> Single classification Many to many Labelling videos Sequences of images -> Many labels But even good for non-sequential data How [[Recurrent Neural Network]]s Work RNNs have an “internal state” that is updated as a sequence is processed Sampling what the model thinks is the next character, then feeding that back into the model as next input Example: Language Modelling Note the use of [[One-Hot Encoding]] on the input.

item.title: Blake Richards on Why He is Skeptical of Existential Risk From AI - EA Forum
item.description: Blake Richards on Why He is Skeptical of Existential Risk From AI - EA Forum Training in a Domain is Better for [[Transfer Effects]] Than Training Across All Tasks The Gato paper from DeepMind actually shows, if you look at their data, that they’re still getting better transfer effects if you train in domain than if you train across all possible tasks.

item.title: Supervised Learning
item.description: Supervised Learning Learn a function to map $x\to y$. We are given a large dataset $$D_n = {(x^{(1)}, y^{(1)}), …, (x^{(n)}, y^{(n)})}$$

item.title: Unsupervised Learning
item.description: Unsupervised Learning No data, just labels! Learn some underlying hidden structure of the data. Instead, one is given a data set and generally expected to find some patterns or structure inherent in it.

item.title: Copyright for AI Generated Content
item.description: Copyright for AI Generated Content The US Copyright Office Review Board (“Board”) rejected a request to register a computer-generated image of a landscape for copyright protection, explaining that a work must be created by a human being to obtain a copyright.

item.title: Scaling Laws for Neural Language Models
item.description: Scaling Laws for Neural Language Models Larger models are significantly more sample-efficient, such that optimally compute-efficient training involves training very large models on a relatively modest amount of data and stopping significantly before convergence.

item.title: The Bitter Lesson
item.description: The Bitter Lesson We must realize that AI does not work the same way humans do. Embrace [[Scaling Computation]]. ^0e3733

item.title: Why is Sanskrit the Best Language for AI?
item.description: Why is Sanskrit the Best Language for AI? Rick Briggs suggests that Sanskrit, an ancient form of communication, is a naturally spoken language with mechanics and grammatical rules that would allow an artificial intelligence to more accurately interpret sentences during linguistic analysis.

item.title: Perceptron Algorithm
item.description: Perceptron Algorithm One of the earliest examples of [[Artificial Intelligence|Deep Learning]], used to discern difference between alphabet. A model that updates on the basis of whether the dot product is positive or negative.
